Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Single pole and robotic arm
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=236201729; y=mqa86IjNqvnkQlETNftvaZ7bibT8zINf_vEV-KsP6HUG3BEu

			Hi,

Thank you for your quick reply. I first have a very simple question :
Does NEAT save somewhere the best organism ever encountered ? Is there
any form of elitism ? I can't find it in the source code (standard
neat).

My second question :

When I use NEAT for many generations (2000, for instance), I get
bigger and bigger networks
(http://webia.lip6.fr/~mouret/nn_cartpole_neat.pdf). This seems
logical since NEAT does not any node removing operator. I'm trying to
reduce the add_node and add_connection probabilities but I think I
should stop the evolution sometimes.
=> When should I end the evolution ? Considering that I'm trying to
compare NEAT to some other neuro-evolution methods, I'd like to use
the same number of generations to be as fair as possible.

From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>

> > I'm starting to evaluate NEAT for simple robotics problems and I 
> need
> > your advices to be sure to use the correct starting networks and
> > parameters. I work on two simple problems: single pole balancing
> > (non-markovian) and simple 3-DOF robotic arm control.
> > 
[...]
> > -> how could I improve these results ? Does someone has some 
> benchmark
> > results on this classical problem ?
> > 
> 
> Have you tried using p2nv.ne (the non-Markovian parameters) instead 
> of pole2_markov?  Perhaps they would do better.  Perhaps a smaller 
> mut_weight_power (weight mutation power) would help too, since you 
> are concerned very small oscillations that may be hard to damp 
> without our very fine-grained weight adjustments.


=> I've tried this and I was not able to improve the results in any
substancial way. 

Thanks.

Best regards,
-- 
Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
http://animatlab.lip6.fr/~mouret
tel : (+33) 6 28 35 10 49
